awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: The tiniest galaxies in the Universe as testbeds of fundamental physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). One of the open fundamental questions about the universe is the fraction of matter that is ‘cold dark matter,’ which does not interact with light. This fraction, called LAMBDA_CDM, governs how galaxies form and evolve in the standard cosmological model. While the model works very well for larger galaxies like the Milky Way, there are challenges for smaller galaxies, such as dwarf galaxies. This project will employ undergraduate students at a Hispanic Serving Institution in cutting-edge cosmological research using the latest models to explore fundamental questions about our universe, such as ‘what is the nature of dark matter?’ The students will apply these models to low-mass galaxies to make predictions that will be testable with future observations. Students will be recruited through the Cal-Bridge Program, which focuses on students from under-represented backgrounds. 

Students will use observations of ultra-faint dwarf galaxies to constrain cosmological models of dwarf galaxy formation around larger galaxies. They will produce testable predictions of the number of dwarf galaxies around a Milky Way-size galaxy for given input parameters such as LAMBDA_CDM, which will place constraints on the amount of cold dark matter in the Universe. They will also place limits on the sources and timing of the cosmic reionizing background, make predictions for the effect of dwarf galaxy major mergers on stellar kinematics, and test the effect of the presence of a Milky Way-size galaxy on the results of these same experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project "LEAPS-MPS: The Universe's Tiniest Galaxies as Testbeds of Fundamental Physics," primarily executed at Cal Poly Pomona, has made important strides in understanding the Universe, particularly through investigating dark-matter dominated low-mass galaxies. Through high-resolution simulations of the Universe’s tiniest known galaxies, the project sheds light on galaxy formation, dark matter, the era during which the Universe became reionized, and the interaction of dwarf galaxies with larger systems like the Milky Way.

Advancing Knowledge Across Fields

The project's research activities, including simulating a major merger between two low-mass galaxies, determining the lowest mass dark matter halo that can host a galaxy, and investigating the brightness of low-mass galaxies, have significantly advanced our understanding of the Universe. The research, completed largely by undergraduate students during the lifetime of this grant, offers insight into outstanding questions in astrophysics. For instance, two key findings of this work are that a) galaxies are predicted to form in dark matter halos with masses lower than what was previously believed, and b) that the observed ultra-faint galaxies around the Milky Way may have undetected stellar halos surrounding their known stellar populations.

Benefiting Society and Inspiring Future Scientists

A key goal of the project was outreach and education - training undergraduate students in coding, simulation analysis, presenting their research to colleagues and peers, as well as telescope operation and community outreach. This project not only led to improvements in the skills of several future astrophysicists, but also made science more accessible to the public in the Los Angeles and Inland Empire areas. BUILD (Bringing the Universe into Inland empire and Los angeles Districts) star party events at local schools, with a public talk and student-led telescope viewings, engaged over 500 students and family members. Seeing older students that looked like them running the outreach events showed local students that advanced research is within reach for everyone.

Organized Mentoring Plan

The project had a structured approach to student research. We held regular meetings in which each student would take turns summarizing their project, and then giving an update on where they were at, with other students and the PI asking questions. This allowed for individualized student mentoring within a broader research group setting, preparing students for entering a research group in graduate school. The group meetings were alternated with individual meetings, which allowed for the PI to troubleshoot individual student issues, which helped students see how coding in research advances in real time.

Qualifications and Resources

The team, led by the PI, was well-equipped to handle the project's goals. Access to supercomputing resources and collaboration with established institutions like Caltech, UCSD, UC Irvine, UC Davis and UT Austin, further expanded the students' mentoring networks.

Major Outcomes and Achievements

1.  Research Excellence: Students contributed to groundbreaking research, with eight presenting at the American Astronomical Society (AAS) conferences in Pasadena and Albuquerque. An additional student presented his work at a galaxy formation conference at UC Riverside.

2.  Student Development: The project facilitated student learning -- students developed skills in coding, data analysis, and scientific communication. Their involvement in high-level research led to six students being accepted into prestigious graduate programs (3 Ph.D, 2 M.S. and one bridge program).

3.  Public Engagement and Outreach: The success of the CPP star parties, as well as the re-starting of BUILD events, complete with public talks and student-led telescope viewings at local schools, exemplified the project's commitment to making science accessible, and to facilitating the next generation of scientists' ability to see themselves in these roles.  

Training and Professional Development Opportunities

The project provided comprehensive training in Python, Linux, academic reading, and telescope operation. Additionally, it offered a unique opportunity for students to engage with cutting-edge research and connect with experienced mentors.

Dissemination to Communities of Interest

Findings were shared at conferences and University events. Notably, at the American Astronomical Society conference, two students’ poster won an honorable mention in the prestigious Chambliss poster competition. Furthermore, the principal investigator presented student work at an international conference, further spreading the project's impact.

Impact Beyond Academia

The project's most significant societal contribution lies in its inspiring effect on young minds and the public. By bringing the universe closer to students and families through student-led telescope events at local schools, the project showcased the career possibilities within reach for students from diverse backgrounds.

In conclusion, "LEAPS-MPS: The Universe's Tiniest Galaxies as Testbeds of Fundamental Physics" has not only advanced our understanding of the Universe, dark matter, and galaxy formation, but also nurtured the next generation of scientists and brought the wonders of the universe to the broader public. Through the funds provided by this grant, we showed that studying the Universe is something accessible to anyone who wants to further knowledge, and that astronomy can transcend the boundaries of academia and enrich society as a whole.
